name: Found footage and the first camcorder
description: Amateur filmmakers turned the camera on their own lives when camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P came on the market. The style of footage filmed on camcorders has inspired many fictional films, particularly in the horror genre.

key_work.title: Sony Betamovie BMC-100P
key_work.brief_description: This Sony Betamovie BMC-100P model of camera carried Betamax cassette tapes, which were introduced by Sony in 1975. It was the first consumer camcorder, including both camera and recorder in a single unit that would become standard in the years to follow.

end.title: Reality Bites
end.creator_credit: Ben Stiller, Eugenie Bafaloukos, Danny DeVito, Michael Shamberg, Jersey Films, Universal Pictures, Sharon Seymour and Helen Childress
end.brief_description: A small circle of friends suffering from post-collegiate blues must confront the hard truth about life, love and the pursuit of gainful employment. As they struggle to map out survival guides for the future, the Gen-X quartet soon begins to realize that reality isn’t all it’s cracked up to be.

constellations_other.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

recommendations.quote: Not only did The Blair Witch Project scare up $248.6 million USD at the box office, it also created the first viral marketing campaign (which led many people to believe it was true) and ushered in the era of hand-held doco-style found footage horror films.

links.description: Ben Stiller’s directorial debut, Reality Bites (1994) was a romantic comedy that featured characters filming video testimonials on handheld camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P. It’s an element that would be adapted for The Blair Witch Project (1999) a few years later.

end.title: Paranormal Activity
end.creator_credit: Oren Peli, Amir Zbeda, Jason Blum, Blumhouse Productions and Solana Films
end.brief_description: After a young, middle-class couple moves into what seems like a typical suburban house, they become increasingly disturbed by a presence that may or may not be demonic but is certainly the most active in the middle of the night. Followed by five terrifying installments in the franchise, this is the original found-footage shocker that started it all.

links.description: Twisting the non-fiction documentary format with a fictional storyline, The Blair Witch Project (1999) featured characters filming the terror on camcorders as they experience it. It became the most financially successful independent film until another found footage film, Paranormal Activity (2007).

links.description: Dethroning Blair Witch, Paranormal Activity (2009) became a massive box-office success, kickstarted a found footage horror franchise and began the dominance of production company Blumhouse. It also reignited the genre, with Chronicle (2012) arriving shortly after.

end.title: Stabbing at Leia's
end.brief_description: You may or may not know Josh Trank directed a short film that was inspired by the Star Wars universe called “Stabbing at Leia’s.” It was made back in 2007 and it was done in the same style that he directed Chronicle. In fact, this is the short that help him land the Chronicle directing gig.

links.description: Chronicle (2012) was the first found footage superhero film in the genre, with the characters superpowers meaning phones and camcorders were able to be moved to angles previously unrealistic for the scenarios. Director Josh Trank made his directorial debut on the movie after short Stabbing at Leia’s 22nd Birthday (2007).

constellations_other.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_other.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

links.description: Stabbing at Leia’s 22nd Birthday (2007) was one of the first longer form viral videos, with the found footage short film written and directed by Josh Trank gaining traction on YouTube. With a catchy title, it was actually a bait and switch riff on Star Wars (1977) at a regular house party.
